007package renderer.framebuffer;
008
009import java.awt.Color;
010import java.awt.Dimension;
011import java.io.FileInputStream;
012import java.io.FileOutputStream;
013import java.io.FileNotFoundException;
014import java.io.IOException;
015import java.io.RandomAccessFile;
016import java.nio.ByteBuffer;
017import java.nio.channels.FileChannel;
018import java.awt.image.BufferedImage;
019import javax.imageio.ImageIO;
020
021/**
022    A {@code FrameBuffer} represents a two-dimensional array of pixel data.
023    The pixel data is stored as a one dimensional array in row-major order.
024    The first row of data should be displayed as the top row of pixels
025    in the image.
026<p>
027    A {@link Viewport} is a two-dimensional sub array of a {@code FrameBuffer}.
028<p>
029    A {@code FrameBuffer} has a default {@link Viewport}. The current {@link Viewport}
030    is represented by its upper-left-hand corner and its lower-right-hand
031    corner.
032<p>
033    {@code FrameBuffer} and {@link Viewport} coordinates act like Java
034    {@link java.awt.Graphics2D} coordinates; the positive x direction is
035    to the right and the positive y direction is downward.
036*/
037public final class FrameBuffer
038{
039   private static final double Z_BUFFER_MAX_DEPTH = -Double.MAX_VALUE;
040
041   public final int width;  // framebuffer's width  (Java calls this a "blank final")
042   public final int height; // framebuffer's height (Java calls this a "blank final")
043   public final int[] pixel_buffer; // contains each pixel's color data for a rendered frame
044   public final double[] z_buffer;  // contains each pixel's depth data
045   public Color bgColorFB = Color.black; // default background color
046   public final Viewport vp;             // default viewport (another "blank final")
047
048   /**
049      Construct a {@code FrameBuffer} with the given dimensions.
050   <p>
051      Initialize the {@code FrameBuffer} to hold all black pixels.
052   <p>
053      The default {@link Viewport} is the whole {@code FrameBuffer}.
054
055      @param w  width of the {@code FrameBuffer}.
056      @param h  height of the {@code FrameBuffer}.
057   */
058   public FrameBuffer(final int w, final int h) {
059      this(w, h, Color.black);
060   }
061
062
063   /**
064      Construct a {@code FrameBuffer} with the given dimensions.
065   <p>
066      Initialize the {@code FrameBuffer} to the given {@link Color}.
067   <p>
068      The default {@link Viewport} is the whole {@code FrameBuffer}.
069
070      @param w  width of the {@code FrameBuffer}.
071      @param h  height of the {@code FrameBuffer}.
072      @param c  background {@link Color} for the {@code FrameBuffer}
073   */
074   public FrameBuffer(final int w, final int h, final Color c) {
075      this.width  = w; // fill in the "blank final"
076      this.height = h; // fill in the "blank final"
077
078      // Create the pixel buffer (fill in the "blank final").
079      this.pixel_buffer = new int[this.width * this.height];
080
081      // Create the z-buffer (the depth buffer).
082      z_buffer = new double[this.width * this.height];
083
084      // Initialize the pixel and z buffer.
085      this.bgColorFB = c;
086      clearFB(c);
087
088      // Create the default viewport.
089      this.vp = this.new Viewport();
090   }
091
092
093   /**
094      Create a {@code FraameBuffer} from the pixel data of another
095      {@code FrameBuffer}.
096   <p>
097      The size of the new {@code FrameBuffer} will be the size of the
098      source {@link FrameBuffer}.
099   <p>
100      The default {@link Viewport} is the whole {@code FrameBuffer}.
101
102      @param sourceFB  {@link FrameBuffer} to use as the source of the pixel data
103   */
104   public FrameBuffer(final FrameBuffer sourceFB) {
105
106      width  = sourceFB.width;  // fill in the "blank final"
107      height = sourceFB.height; // fill in the "blank final"
108
109      // Create the pixel buffer (fill in the "blank final").
110      this.pixel_buffer = new int[width * height];
111
112      // Read pixel data, one pixel at a time, from the source FrameBuffer.
113      for (int y = 0; y < height; ++y) {
114         for (int x = 0; x < width; ++x) {
115            setPixelFB(x, y, sourceFB.getPixelFB(x,y));
116         }
117      }
118
119      // Create the z-buffer (the depth buffer).
120      z_buffer = new double[this.width * this.height];
121      clearZB();
122
123      // Create the default viewport.
124      this.vp = this.new Viewport();
125   }
126
127
128   /**
129      Create a {@code FrameBuffer} from the pixel data of a {@link Viewport}.
130   <p>
131      The size of the new {@code FrameBuffer} will be the size of the
132      source {@code Viewport}.
133   <p>
134      The default {@link Viewport} is the whole {@code FrameBuffer}.
135
136      @param sourceVP  {@link Viewport} to use as the source of the pixel data
137   */
138   public FrameBuffer(final Viewport sourceVP) {
139
140      width  = sourceVP.getWidthVP();  // fill in the "blank final"
141      height = sourceVP.getHeightVP(); // fill in the "blank final"
142
143      // Create the pixel buffer (fill in the "blank final").
144      this.pixel_buffer = new int[width * height];
145
146      // Read pixel data, one pixel at a time, from the source Viewport.
147      for (int y = 0; y < height; ++y) {
148         for (int x = 0; x < width; ++x) {
149            setPixelFB(x, y, sourceVP.getPixelVP(x,y));
150         }
151      }
152
153      // Create the z-buffer (the depth buffer).
154      z_buffer = new double[this.width * this.height];
155
156      // Read depth data, one pixel at a time, from the source Viewport.
157      for (int y = 0; y < height; ++y) {
158         for (int x = 0; x < width; ++x) {
159            setDepthFB(x, y, sourceVP.getDepthVP(x,y));
160         }
161      }
162
163      // Create the default viewport.
164      this.vp = this.new Viewport();
165   }
166
167
168   /**
169      Construct a {@code FrameBuffer} from a PPM image file.
170   <p>
171      The size of the {@code FrameBuffer} will be the size of the image.
172   <p>
173      The default {@link Viewport} is the whole {@code FrameBuffer}.
174   <p>
175      This can be used to initialize a {@code FrameBuffer}
176      with a background image.
177
178      @param inputFileName  must name a PPM image file with magic number P6.
179   */
180   public FrameBuffer(final String inputFileName) {
181      FileInputStream fis = null;
182      Dimension fbDim = null;
183      try {
184         fis = new FileInputStream(inputFileName);
185         fbDim = getPPMdimensions(inputFileName, fis);
186      }
187      catch (IOException e) {
188         System.err.printf("ERROR! Could not open %s\n", inputFileName);
189         e.printStackTrace(System.err);
190         System.exit(-1);
191      }
192
193      this.width  = fbDim.width;  // fill in the "blank final"
194      this.height = fbDim.height; // fill in the "blank final"
195
196      // Create the pixel buffer (fill in the "blank final").
197      this.pixel_buffer = new int[width * height];
198
199      // Initialize the pixel buffer.
200      try {
201         setPixels(0, 0, width, height, inputFileName, fis);
202         fis.close();
203      }
204      catch (IOException e) {
205         System.err.printf("ERROR! Could not read %s\n", inputFileName);
206         e.printStackTrace(System.err);
207         System.exit(-1);
208      }
209
210      // Create the z-buffer (the depth buffer).
211      z_buffer = new double[this.width * this.height];
212      clearZB();
213
214      // Create the default viewport.
215      this.vp = this.new Viewport();
216   }
217
218
219   /**
220      Get the pixel data's dimensions from a PPM file.
221
222      @param inputFile  must name a PPM image file with magic number P6
223      @param fis        input stream to the PPM image file
224      @throws IOException if there is a problem with {@code fis}
225      @return a {@link Dimension} object holding the PPM file's width and height
226   */
227   private Dimension getPPMdimensions(final String inputFile, final FileInputStream fis)
228   throws IOException {
229   // Read the meta data in a PPM file.
230   // http://stackoverflow.com/questions/2693631/read-ppm-file-and-store-it-in-an-array-coded-with-c
231      // Read image format string "P6".
232      String magicNumber = "";
233      char c = (char)fis.read();
234      while (c != '\n') {
235         magicNumber += c;
236         c = (char)fis.read();
237      }
238      if (! magicNumber.trim().startsWith("P6")) {
239         System.err.printf("ERROR! Improper PPM number in file %s\n", inputFile);
240         System.exit(-1);
241      }
242
243      c = (char)fis.read();
244      if ( '#' == c ) { // read (and discard) IrfanView comment
245         while (c != '\n') {
246            c = (char)fis.read();
247         }
248         c = (char)fis.read();
249      }
250
251      // Read image dimensions.
252      String widthDim = "";
253      while (c != ' ' && c != '\n') {
254         widthDim += c;
255         c = (char)fis.read();
256      }
257
258      String heightDim = "";
259      c = (char)fis.read();
260      while (c != '\n') {
261         heightDim += c;
262         c = (char)fis.read();
263      }
264
265      final int width  = Integer.parseInt(widthDim.trim());
266      final int height = Integer.parseInt(heightDim.trim());
267      return new Dimension(width, height);
268   }
269
270
271   /**
272      Initialize a rectangle of pixels from a PPM image file.
273
274      @param rec_ul_x   upper left hand x-coordinate of the rectangle of pixels
275      @param rec_ul_y   upper left hand y-coordinate of the rectangle of pixels
276      @param width      width of the pixel data to read from the PPM file
277      @param height     height of the pixel data to read from the PPM file
278      @param inputFile  must name a PPM image file with magic number P6
279      @param fis        input stream to the PPM image file
280      @throws IOException if there is a problem with {@code fis}
281   */
282   private void setPixels(final int rec_ul_x, final int rec_ul_y,
283                          final int width,    final int height,
284                          final String inputFile, final FileInputStream fis)
285   throws IOException {
286   // Read the pixel data in a PPM file.
287   // http://stackoverflow.com/questions/2693631/read-ppm-file-and-store-it-in-an-array-coded-with-c
288      // Read image rgb dimensions (which we don't use).
289      char c = (char)fis.read();
290      while (c != '\n') {
291         c = (char)fis.read();
292      }
293
294      // Create a small data array.
295      final byte[] pixelData = new byte[3];
296
297      // Read pixel data, one pixel at a time, from the PPM file.
298      for (int y = 0; y < height; ++y) {
299         for (int x = 0; x < width; ++x) {
300            if ( fis.read(pixelData, 0, 3) != 3 ) {
301               System.err.printf("ERROR! Could not load %s\n", inputFile);
302               System.exit(-1);
303            }
304            int r = pixelData[0];
305            int g = pixelData[1];
306            int b = pixelData[2];
307            if (r < 0) r = 256+r;  // convert from signed byte to unsigned byte
308            if (g < 0) g = 256+g;
309            if (b < 0) b = 256+b;
310            setPixelFB(rec_ul_x + x, rec_ul_y + y, new Color(r, g, b));
311         }
312      }
313   }
314
315
316   /**
317      Get the width of this {@code FrameBuffer}.
318
319      @return width of this {@code FrameBuffer}
320   */
321   public int getWidthFB() {
322      return width;
323   }
324
325
326   /**
327      Get the height of this {@code FrameBuffer}.
328
329      @return height of this {@code FrameBuffer}
330   */
331   public int getHeightFB() {
332      return height;
333   }
334
335
336   /**
337      Get this {@code FrameBuffer}'s default {@code Viewport}.
338
339      @return this {@code FrameBuffer}'s default {@code Viewport}
340   */
341   public Viewport getViewport() {
342      return this.vp;
343   }
344
345
346   /**
347      Set the default {@code Viewport} to be this whole {@code FrameBuffer}.
348   */
349   public void setViewport() {
350      this.vp.setViewport(0, 0, this.width, this.height);
351   }
352
353
354   /**
355      Set the default {@code Viewport} with the given upper-left-hand corner,
356      width and height within this {@code FrameBuffer}.
357
358      @param vp_ul_x  upper left hand x-coordinate of default {@code Viewport}
359      @param vp_ul_y  upper left hand y-coordinate of default {@code Viewport}
360      @param width    default {@code Viewport}'s width
361      @param height   default {@code Viewport}'s height
362   */
363   public void setViewport(final int vp_ul_x, final int vp_ul_y,
364                           final int width,   final int height) {
365      this.vp.setViewport(vp_ul_x, vp_ul_y, width, height);
366   }
367
368
369   /**
370      Get the {@code FrameBuffer}'s background color.
371
372      @return the {@code FrameBuffer}'s background {@link Color}
373   */
374   public Color getBackgroundColorFB() {
375      return bgColorFB;
376   }
377
378
379   /**
380      Set the {@code FrameBuffer}'s background color.
381      <p>
382      NOTE: This method does not clear the pixels of the
383      {@code FrameBuffer} to the given {@link Color}. To
384      actually change all the {@code FrameBuffer}'s pixels
385      to the given {@link Color}, use the {@link clearFB}
386      method.
387
388      @param c  {@code FrameBuffer}'s new background {@link Color}
389   */
390   public void setBackgroundColorFB(final Color c) {
391      bgColorFB = c;
392   }
393
394
395   /**
396      Clear the {@code FrameBuffer} using its background color.
397   */
398   public void clearFB() {
399      clearFB(bgColorFB);
400   }
401
402
403   /**
404      Clear the {@code FrameBuffer} using the given {@link Color}.
405
406      @param c  {@link Color} to clear {@code FrameBuffer} with
407   */
408   public void clearFB(final Color c) {
409      final int rgb = c.getRGB();
410      for (int y = 0; y < height; ++y) {
411         for (int x = 0; x < width; ++x) {
412            setPixelFB(x, y, rgb);
413         }
414      }
415      // clear the z-buffer (the depth buffer)
416      clearZB();
417   }
418
419
420   /**
421      Clear the {@code FrameBuffer}'s z-buffer (the depth buffer).
422   */
423   public void clearZB() {
424      for (int y = 0; y < height; ++y) {
425         for (int x = 0; x < width; ++x) {
426            setDepthFB(x, y, Z_BUFFER_MAX_DEPTH);
427         }
428      }
429   }
430
431
432   /**
433      Get the {@link Color} of the pixel with coordinates
434      {@code (x,y)} in the {@code FrameBuffer}.
435
436      @param x  horizontal coordinate within the {@code FrameBuffer}
437      @param y  vertical coordinate within the {@code FrameBuffer}
438      @return the {@link Color} of the pixel at the given pixel coordinates
439   */
440   public Color getPixelFB(final int x, final int y) {
441      final int index = (y*width + x);
442      try {
443         final int rgb = pixel_buffer[index];
444         return new Color(rgb);
445      }
446      catch(ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException e) {
447         System.err.println("FrameBuffer: Bad pixel coordinate"
448                                          + " (" + x + ", " + y +")"
449                                          + " [w="+width+", h="+height+"]");
450       //e.printStackTrace(System.err);
451         return Color.black;
452      }
453   }
454
455
456   /**
457      Get the depth from the z-buffer of the pixel with coordinates
458      {@code (x,y)} in the {@code FrameBuffer}.
459
460      @param x  horizontal coordinate within the {@code FrameBuffer}
461      @param y  vertical coordinate within the {@code FrameBuffer}
462      @return the depth of the current pixel at the given pixel coordinates
463   */
464   public double getDepthFB(final int x, final int y) {
465      final int index = (y*width + x);
466      try {
467         return z_buffer[index];
468      }
469      catch(ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException e) {
470         System.err.println("Z-Buffer: Bad pixel coordinate (" + x + ", " + y +")");
471       //e.printStackTrace(System.err);
472         return Z_BUFFER_MAX_DEPTH;
473      }
474   }
475
476
477   /**
478      Set the {@link Color} of the pixel with coordinates
479      {@code (x,y)} in the {@code FrameBuffer}.
480
481      @param x  horizontal coordinate within the {@code FrameBuffer}
482      @param y  vertical coordinate within the {@code FrameBuffer}
483      @param c  {@link Color} for the pixel at the given pixel coordinates
484   */
485   public void setPixelFB(final int x, final int y, final Color c) {
486      final int index = (y*width + x);
487      try {
488         pixel_buffer[index] = c.getRGB();
489      }
490      catch(ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException e) {
491         System.err.println("FrameBuffer: Bad pixel coordinate"
492                                          + " (" + x + ", " + y +")"
493                                          + " [w="+width+", h="+height+"]");
494       //e.printStackTrace(System.err);
495      }
496   }
497
498
499   /**
500      Set the {@link Color} and depth of the pixel with coordinates
501      {@code (x,y)} in the {@code FrameBuffer} and the z-buffer.
502
503      @param x  horizontal coordinate within the {@code FrameBuffer}
504      @param y  vertical coordinate within the {@code FrameBuffer}
505      @param c  {@link Color} for the pixel at the given pixel coordinates
506      @param z  depth for the pixel at the given pixel coordinates
507   */
508   public void setPixelFB(final int x, final int y, final Color c, final double z) {
509      setPixelFB(x, y, c);
510      setDepthFB(x, y, z);
511   }
512
513
514   /**
515      Set the combined RGB value of the pixel with coordinates
516      {@code (x,y)} in the {@code FrameBuffer}.
517
518      @param x  horizontal coordinate within the {@code FrameBuffer}
519      @param y  vertical coordinate within the {@code FrameBuffer}
520      @param c  combined RGB value for the pixel at the given pixel coordinates
521   */
522   public void setPixelFB(final int x, final int y, final int c) {
523      final int index = (y*width + x);
524      try {
525         pixel_buffer[index] = c;
526      }
527      catch(ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException e) {
528         System.err.println("FrameBuffer: Bad pixel coordinate"
529                                          + " (" + x + ", " + y +")"
530                                          + " [w="+width+", h="+height+"]");
531       //e.printStackTrace(System.err);
532      }
533   }
534
535
536   /**
537      Set the combined RGB value and depth of the pixel with coordinates
538      {@code (x,y)} in the {@code FrameBuffer}.
539
540      @param x  horizontal coordinate within the {@code FrameBuffer}
541      @param y  vertical coordinate within the {@code FrameBuffer}
542      @param c  combined RGB value for the pixel at the given pixel coordinates
543      @param z  depth for the pixel at the given pixel coordinates
544   */
545   public void setPixelFB(final int x, final int y, final int c, final double z) {
546      setPixelFB(x, y, c);
547      setDepthFB(x, y, z);
548   }
549
550
551   /**
552      Set the depth in the z-buffer of the pixel with coordinates
553      {@code (x,y)} in the {@code FrameBuffer}.
554
555      @param x  horizontal coordinate within the {@code FrameBuffer}
556      @param y  vertical coordinate within the {@code FrameBuffer}
557      @param z  depth for the pixel at the given pixel coordinates
558   */
559   public void setDepthFB(final int x, final int y, final double z) {
560      final int index = (y*width + x);
561      try {
562         z_buffer[index] = z;
563      }
564      catch(ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException e) {
565         System.err.println("Z-Buffer: Bad pixel coordinate (" + x + ", " + y +")");
566       //e.printStackTrace(System.err);
567      }
568   }
569
570
571   /**
572      Create a new {@code FrameBuffer} containing the pixel data
573      from just the red plane of this {@code FrameBuffer}.
574
575      @return {@code FrameBuffer} object holding just red pixel data from this {@code FrameBuffer}
576   */
577   public FrameBuffer convertRed2FB() {
578      final FrameBuffer red_fb = new FrameBuffer(this.width, this.height);
579      red_fb.bgColorFB = this.bgColorFB;
580
581      // Copy the framebuffer's red values into the new framebuffer's pixel buffer.
582      for (int y = 0; y < this.height; ++y) {
583         for (int x = 0; x < this.width; ++x) {
584            final Color c = new Color(this.getPixelFB(x, y).getRed(), 0, 0);
585            red_fb.setPixelFB(x, y, c);
586         }
587      }
588      return red_fb;
589   }
590
591
592   /**
593      Create a new {@code FrameBuffer} containing the pixel data
594      from just the green plane of this {@code FrameBuffer}.
595
596      @return {@code FrameBuffer} object holding just green pixel data from this {@code FrameBuffer}
597   */
598   public FrameBuffer convertGreen2FB() {
599      final FrameBuffer green_fb = new FrameBuffer(this.width, this.height);
600      green_fb.bgColorFB = this.bgColorFB;
601
602      // Copy the framebuffer's green values into the new framebuffer's pixel buffer.
603      for (int y = 0; y < this.height; ++y) {
604         for (int x = 0; x < this.width; ++x) {
605            final Color c = new Color(0, this.getPixelFB(x, y).getGreen(), 0);
606            green_fb.setPixelFB(x, y, c);
607         }
608      }
609      return green_fb;
610   }
611
612
613   /**
614      Create a new {@code FrameBuffer} containing the pixel data
615      from just the blue plane of this {@code FrameBuffer}.
616
617      @return {@code FrameBuffer} object holding just blue pixel data from this {@code FrameBuffer}
618   */
619   public FrameBuffer convertBlue2FB() {
620      final FrameBuffer blue_fb = new FrameBuffer(this.width, this.height);
621      blue_fb.bgColorFB = this.bgColorFB;
622
623      // Copy the framebuffer's blue values into the new framebuffer's pixel buffer.
624      for (int y = 0; y < this.height; ++y) {
625         for (int x = 0; x < this.width; ++x) {
626            final Color c = new Color(0, 0, this.getPixelFB(x, y).getBlue());
627            blue_fb.setPixelFB(x, y, c);
628         }
629      }
630      return blue_fb;
631   }
632
633
634   /**
635      Write this {@code FrameBuffer} to the specified PPM file.
636   <p>
637      <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Netpbm_format" target="_top">
638               https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Netpbm_format</a>
639
640      @param filename  name of PPM image file to hold {@code FrameBuffer} data
641   */
642   public void dumpFB2File(final String filename) {
643      dumpPixels2File(0, 0, width-1, height-1, filename);
644   }
645
646
647   /**
648      Write a rectangular sub array of pixels from this {@code FrameBuffer}
649      to the specified PPM file.
650   <p>
651      <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Netpbm_format#PPM_example" target="_top">
652               https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Netpbm_format#PPM_example</a>
653   <p>
654<a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/2693631/read-ppm-file-and-store-it-in-an-array-coded-with-c" target="_top">
655         http://stackoverflow.com/questions/2693631/read-ppm-file-and-store-it-in-an-array-coded-with-c</a>
656
657      @param ul_x      upper left hand x-coordinate of pixel data rectangle
658      @param ul_y      upper left hand y-coordinate of pixel data rectangle
659      @param lr_x      lower right hand x-coordinate of pixel data rectangle
660      @param lr_y      lower right hand y-coordinate of pixel data rectangle
661      @param filename  name of PPM image file to hold pixel data
662   */
663   public void dumpPixels2File(final int ul_x, final int ul_y,
664                               final int lr_x, final int lr_y,
665                               final String filename) {
666      final int p_width  = lr_x - ul_x + 1;
667      final int p_height = lr_y - ul_y + 1;
668
669      try {
670         // Header (meta data) for the PPM file.
671         final byte[] header = ("P6\n" + p_width + " " + p_height + "\n" + 255 + "\n").getBytes();
672
673         final FileChannel fc = new RandomAccessFile(filename, "rw").getChannel();
674         final ByteBuffer mbb = fc.map(FileChannel.MapMode.READ_WRITE,
675                                       0,
676                                       header.length + 3 * pixel_buffer.length);
677
678         // Write data to the memory-mapped file.
679         // Write the PPM header information first.
680         for (int i = 0; i < header.length; ++i) {
681            mbb.put(i, header[i]);
682         }
683         // Copy all the pixel data to the memory-mapped file, one row at a time.
684         int index = header.length;
685         for (int n = 0; n < p_height; ++n) {
686            // read data from the top row of the data buffer
687            // down towards the bottom row
688            for (int i = 0; i < p_width * 3; i += 3) {
689               final int rgb = pixel_buffer[((ul_y+n)*width + ul_x) + i/3];
690               final Color c = new Color(rgb);
691               mbb.put(index + 0, (byte)(c.getRed()));
692               mbb.put(index + 1, (byte)(c.getGreen()));
693               mbb.put(index + 2, (byte)(c.getBlue()));
694               index += 3;
695            }
696         }
697         fc.close();
698      }
699      catch (IOException e) {
700         System.err.printf("ERROR! Could not write to file %s\n", filename);
701         e.printStackTrace(System.err);
702         System.exit(-1);
703      }
704   }
705
706
707   /**
708      Write this {@code FrameBuffer} to the specified image file
709      using the specified file format.
710
711      @param filename    name of the image file to hold framebuffer data
712      @param formatName  informal name of the image format
713   */
714   public void dumpFB2File(final String filename, final String formatName) {
715      dumpPixels2File(0, 0, width-1, height-1, filename, formatName);
716   }
717
718
719   /**
720      Write a rectangular sub array of pixels from this {@code FrameBuffer}
721      to the specified image file using the specified file format.
722   <p>
723      Use the static method {@link ImageIO#getWriterFormatNames}
724      to find out what informal image format names can be used
725      (for example, png, gif, jpg, bmp).
726
727      @param ul_x        upper left hand x-coordinate of pixel data rectangle
728      @param ul_y        upper left hand y-coordinate of pixel data rectangle
729      @param lr_x        lower right hand x-coordinate of pixel data rectangle
730      @param lr_y        lower right hand y-coordinate of pixel data rectangle
731      @param filename    name of the image file to hold pixel data
732      @param formatName  informal name of the image format
733   */
734   public void dumpPixels2File(final int ul_x, final int ul_y,
735                               final int lr_x, final int lr_y,
736                               final String filename,
737                               final String formatName) {
738      final int p_width  = lr_x - ul_x + 1;
739      final int p_height = lr_y - ul_y + 1;
740
741      try {
742         final FileOutputStream fos = new FileOutputStream(filename);
743       //System.err.printf("Created file %s\n", filename);
744
745         final BufferedImage bi = new BufferedImage(p_width, p_height, BufferedImage.TYPE_INT_RGB);
746         for (int n = 0; n < p_height; ++n) {
747            for (int i = 0; i < p_width; ++i) {
748               final int rgb = pixel_buffer[((ul_y+n)*width + ul_x) + i];
749               bi.setRGB(i, n, rgb);
750            }
751         }
752         ImageIO.write(bi, formatName, fos);
753         fos.close();
754      }
755      catch (FileNotFoundException e) {
756         System.err.printf("ERROR! Could not open file %s\n", filename);
757         e.printStackTrace(System.err);
758         System.exit(-1);
759      }
760      catch (IOException e) {
761         System.err.printf("ERROR! Could not write to file %s\n", filename);
762         e.printStackTrace(System.err);
763         System.exit(-1);
764      }
765   }
766
767
768   /**
769      For debugging very small {@code FrameBuffer} objects.
770
771      @return a {@link String} representation of this {@code FrameBuffer}
772   */
773   @Override
774   public String toString() {
775      String result = "FrameBuffer [w=" + width + ", h=" + height + "]\n";
776      for (int j = 0; j < width; ++j) {
777         result += " r   g   b |";
778      }
779      result += "\n";
780      for (int i = 0; i < height; ++i) {
781         for (int j = 0; j < width; ++j) {
782            final int c = pixel_buffer[(i*width) + j];
783            final Color color = new Color(c);
784            result += String.format("%3d ", color.getRed())
785                     +String.format("%3d ", color.getGreen())
786                     +String.format("%3d|", color.getBlue());
787         }
788         result += "\n";
789      }
790      return result;
791   }
792
793
794   /**
795      A simple test of the {@code FrameBuffer} class.
796   <p>
797      It fills the framebuffer with a test pattern.
798   */
799   public void fbTestPattern() {
800      for (int y = 0; y < this.height; ++y) {
801         for (int x = 0; x < this.width; ++x) {
802            final int gray = (x|y)%255;
803            setPixelFB(x, y, new Color(gray, gray, gray));
804         }
805      }
806   }
807
808
809/*******************************************************************
810   The following code is an inner class of FrameBuffer.
811********************************************************************/
812
813   /**
814      A {@code Viewport} is an inner (non-static nested) class of
815      {@link FrameBuffer}. That means that a {@code Viewport} has
816      access to the pixel data of its "parent" {@link FrameBuffer}.
817   <p>
818      A {@code Viewport} is a two-dimensional sub array of its
819      "parent" {@link FrameBuffer}. A {@code Viewport} is
820      represented by its upper-left-hand corner and its
821      lower-right-hand corner in the {@link FrameBuffer}.
822   <p>
823      When you set a pixel in a {@code Viewport}, you are really
824      setting a pixel in its parent {@link FrameBuffer}.
825   <p>
826      A {@link FrameBuffer} can have multiple {@code Viewport}s.
827   <p>
828      {@code Viewport} coordinates act like Java {@link java.awt.Graphics2D}
829      coordinates; the positive {@code x} direction is to the right and the
830      positive {@code y} direction is downward.
831   */
832   public class Viewport  // inner class (non-static nested class)
833   {
834      // Coordinates of the viewport within the framebuffer.
835      public int vp_ul_x;     // upper-left-hand corner
836      public int vp_ul_y;
837      public int vp_lr_x;     // lower-right-hand corner
838      public int vp_lr_y;
839      public Color bgColorVP;   // the viewport's background color
840
841
842      /**
843         Create a {@code Viewport} that is the whole of its
844         parent {@link FrameBuffer}. The default background
845         {@link Color} is the {@link FrameBuffer}'s background
846         color.
847      */
848      public Viewport() {
849         this(0, 0, width, height, bgColorFB);
850      }
851
852
853      /**
854         Create a {@code Viewport} that is the whole of its
855         parent {@link FrameBuffer} and with the given
856         background color.
857
858         @param c  background {@link Color} for the {@code Viewport}
859      */
860      public Viewport(final Color c) {
861         this(0, 0, width, height, c);
862      }
863
864
865      /**
866         Create a {@code Viewport} with the given upper-left-hand corner,
867         width and height within its parent {@link FrameBuffer}.
868
869         @param vp_ul_x  upper left hand x-coordinate of new {@code Viewport} rectangle
870         @param vp_ul_y  upper left hand y-coordinate of new {@code Viewport} rectangle
871         @param width    {@code Viewport}'s width
872         @param height   {@code Viewport}'s height
873      */
874      public Viewport(final int vp_ul_x, final int vp_ul_y,
875                      final int width,   final int height) {
876         this(vp_ul_x, vp_ul_y, width, height, bgColorFB);
877      }
878
879
880      /**
881         Create a {@code Viewport} with the given upper-left-hand corner,
882         width and height within its parent {@link FrameBuffer}, and with
883         the given background color. (Note: This constructor does not use
884         the background color to set the pixels of this {@code Viewport}.
885         If you want the pixels of this {@code Viewport} to be cleared to
886         the background color, call the {@link clearVP} method.)
887      <p>
888         (Using upper-left-hand corner, width, and height is
889         like Java's {@link java.awt.Rectangle} class and
890         {@link java.awt.Graphics#drawRect} method.)
891
892         @param vp_ul_x  upper left hand x-coordinate of new {@code Viewport} rectangle
893         @param vp_ul_y  upper left hand y-coordinate of new {@code Viewport} rectangle
894         @param width    {@code Viewport}'s width
895         @param height   {@code Viewport}'s height
896         @param c        background {@link Color} for the {@code Viewport}
897      */
898      public Viewport(final int vp_ul_x, final int vp_ul_y,
899                      final int width,   final int height,
900                      final Color c) {
901         this.setViewport(vp_ul_x, vp_ul_y, width, height);
902         this.bgColorVP = c;
903      }
904
905
906      /**
907         Create a {@code Viewport}, within its parent {@link FrameBuffer},
908         from the pixel data of another {@link FrameBuffer}.
909         <p>
910         The size of the {@code Viewport} will be the size of the
911         source {@link FrameBuffer}.
912
913         @param vp_ul_x   upper left hand x-coordinate of new {@code Viewport} rectangle
914         @param vp_ul_y   upper left hand y-coordinate of new {@code Viewport} rectangle
915         @param sourceFB  {@link FrameBuffer} to use as the source of the pixel data
916      */
917      public Viewport(final int vp_ul_x, final int vp_ul_y,
918                      final FrameBuffer sourceFB) {
919         this(vp_ul_x, vp_ul_y, sourceFB.getWidthFB(),
920                                sourceFB.getHeightFB(),
921                                sourceFB.getBackgroundColorFB());
922
923         // Read pixel data, one pixel at a time, from the source FrameBuffer.
924         for (int y = 0; y < sourceFB.getHeightFB(); ++y) {
925            for (int x = 0; x < sourceFB.getWidthFB(); ++x) {
926               this.setPixelVP(x, y, sourceFB.getPixelFB(x,y));
927               this.setDepthVP(x, y, sourceFB.getDepthFB(x,y));
928            }
929         }
930      }
931
932
933      /**
934         Create a {@code Viewport}, within its parent {@link FrameBuffer},
935         from the pixel data of a {@code Viewport}.
936      <p>
937         The size of the new {@code Viewport} will be the size of the
938         source {@code Viewport}.
939      <p>
940         This constructor makes the new {@code Viewport} into a copy of the
941         source {@code Viewport}.
942
943         @param vp_ul_x   upper left hand x-coordinate of new {@code Viewport} rectangle
944         @param vp_ul_y   upper left hand y-coordinate of new {@code Viewport} rectangle
945         @param sourceVP  {@link Viewport} to use as the source of the pixel data
946      */
947      public Viewport(final int vp_ul_x, final int vp_ul_y,
948                      final Viewport sourceVP) {
949         this(vp_ul_x, vp_ul_y, sourceVP.getWidthVP(),
950                                sourceVP.getHeightVP(),
951                                sourceVP.getBackgroundColorVP());
952
953         // Read pixel data, one pixel at a time, from the source Viewport.
954         for (int y = 0; y < sourceVP.getHeightVP(); ++y) {
955            for (int x = 0; x < sourceVP.getWidthVP(); ++x) {
956               this.setPixelVP(x, y, sourceVP.getPixelVP(x,y));
957               this.setDepthVP(x, y, sourceVP.getDepthVP(x,y));
958            }
959         }
960      }
961
962
963      /**
964         Create a {@code Viewport}, within its parent {@link FrameBuffer},
965         from a PPM image file.
966      <p>
967         The size of the {@code Viewport} will be the size of the image.
968      <p>
969         This can be used to initialize a {@code Viewport} with a background image.
970
971         @param vp_ul_x        upper left hand x-coordinate of new {@code Viewport} rectangle
972         @param vp_ul_y        upper left hand y-coordinate of new {@code Viewport} rectangle
973         @param inputFileName  must name a PPM image file with magic number P6.
974      */
975      public Viewport(final int vp_ul_x, final int vp_ul_y,
976                      final String inputFileName) {
977         try {
978            final FileInputStream fis = new FileInputStream(inputFileName);
979
980            final Dimension vpDim = getPPMdimensions(inputFileName, fis);
981
982            this.vp_ul_x = vp_ul_x;
983            this.vp_ul_y = vp_ul_y;
984            this.vp_lr_x = vp_ul_x + vpDim.width - 1;
985            this.vp_lr_y = vp_ul_y + vpDim.height - 1;
986
987            setPixels(vp_ul_x, vp_ul_y, vpDim.width, vpDim.height, inputFileName, fis);
988
989            fis.close();
990
991            this.bgColorVP = bgColorFB;
992         }
993         catch (IOException e) {
994            System.err.printf("ERROR! Could not read %s\n", inputFileName);
995            e.printStackTrace(System.err);
996            System.exit(-1);
997         }
998      }
999
1000
1001      /**
1002         Mutate this {@code Viewport} into the given upper-left-hand corner,
1003         width and height within its parent {@link FrameBuffer}.
1004      <p>
1005         (Using upper-left-hand corner, width, and height is
1006         like Java's {@link java.awt.Rectangle} class and
1007         {@link java.awt.Graphics#drawRect} method.)
1008
1009         @param vp_ul_x  new upper left hand x-coordinate of this {@code Viewport} rectangle
1010         @param vp_ul_y  new upper left hand y-coordinate of this {@code Viewport} rectangle
1011         @param width    {@code Viewport}'s new width
1012         @param height   {@code Viewport}'s new height
1013      */
1014      public void setViewport(final int vp_ul_x, final int vp_ul_y,
1015                              final int width,   final int height) {
1016         this.vp_ul_x = vp_ul_x;
1017         this.vp_ul_y = vp_ul_y;
1018         this.vp_lr_x = vp_ul_x + width - 1;
1019         this.vp_lr_y = vp_ul_y + height - 1;
1020      }
1021
1022
1023      /**
1024         Return a reference to the {@link FrameBuffer} object that
1025         this {@code Viewport} object is nested in.
1026
1027         @return a reference to the {@link FrameBuffer} object that this {@code Viewport} is part of
1028      */
1029      public FrameBuffer getFrameBuffer()
1030      {
1031         return FrameBuffer.this;
1032      }
1033
1034
1035      /**
1036         Get the width of this {@code Viewport}.
1037
1038         @return width of this {@code Viewport} rectangle
1039      */
1040      public int getWidthVP() {
1041         return vp_lr_x - vp_ul_x + 1;
1042      }
1043
1044
1045      /**
1046         Get the height of this {@code Viewport}.
1047
1048         @return height of this {@code Viewport} rectangle
1049      */
1050      public int getHeightVP() {
1051         return vp_lr_y - vp_ul_y + 1;
1052      }
1053
1054
1055      /**
1056         Get the {@code Viewport}'s background color.
1057
1058         @return the {@code Viewport}'s background {@link Color}
1059      */
1060      public Color getBackgroundColorVP() {
1061         return bgColorVP;
1062      }
1063
1064
1065      /**
1066         Set the {@code Viewport}'s background color.
1067         <p>
1068         NOTE: This method does not clear the pixels of the
1069         {@code Viewport} to the given {@link Color}. To
1070         actually change all the {@code Viewport}'s pixels
1071         to the given {@link Color}, use the {@link clearVP}
1072         method.
1073
1074         @param c  {@code Viewport}'s new background {@link Color}
1075      */
1076      public void setBackgroundColorVP(final Color c) {
1077         bgColorVP = c;
1078      }
1079
1080
1081      /**
1082         Clear this {@code Viewport} using its background color.
1083      */
1084      public void clearVP() {
1085         clearVP(bgColorVP);
1086      }
1087
1088
1089      /**
1090         Clear this {@code Viewport} using the given {@link Color}.
1091
1092         @param c  {@link Color} to clear this {@code Viewport} with
1093      */
1094      public void clearVP(final Color c) {
1095         final int wVP = getWidthVP();
1096         final int hVP = getHeightVP();
1097         final int rgb = c.getRGB();
1098         for (int y = 0; y < hVP; ++y) {
1099            for (int x = 0; x < wVP; ++x) {
1100               setPixelVP(x, y, rgb);
1101            }
1102         }
1103         // clear the viewport's z-buffer (the depth buffer)
1104         clearZVP();
1105      }
1106
1107
1108      /**
1109         Clear the viewport's z-buffer (the depth buffer).
1110      */
1111      public void clearZVP() {
1112         final int wVP = getWidthVP();
1113         final int hVP = getHeightVP();
1114         for (int y = 0; y < hVP; ++y) {
1115            for (int x = 0; x < wVP; ++x) {
1116               setDepthVP(x, y, Z_BUFFER_MAX_DEPTH);
1117            }
1118         }
1119      }
1120
1121
1122      /**
1123         Get the {@link Color} of the pixel with coordinates
1124         {@code (x,y)} relative to this {@code Viewport}.
1125
1126         @param x  horizontal coordinate within this {@code Viewport}
1127         @param y  vertical coordinate within this {@code Viewport}
1128         @return the {@link Color} of the current pixel at the given {@code Viewport} coordinates
1129      */
1130      public Color getPixelVP(final int x, final int y) {
1131         return getPixelFB(vp_ul_x + x, vp_ul_y + y);
1132      }
1133
1134
1135      /**
1136         Get the depth from the z-buffer of the pixel with coordinates
1137         {@code (x,y)} relative to the current viewport.
1138
1139         @param x  horizontal coordinate within the current viewport
1140         @param y  vertical coordinate within the current viewport
1141         @return depth of the current pixel at the given viewport coordinates
1142      */
1143      public double getDepthVP(final int x, final int y) {
1144         return getDepthFB(vp_ul_x + x, vp_ul_y + y);
1145      }
1146
1147
1148      /**
1149         Set the {@link Color} of the pixel with coordinates
1150         {@code (x,y)} relative to this {@code Viewport}.
1151
1152         @param x  horizontal coordinate within this {@code Viewport}
1153         @param y  vertical coordinate within this {@code Viewport}
1154         @param c  {@link Color} for the pixel at the given {@code Viewport} coordinates
1155      */
1156      public void setPixelVP(final int x, final int y, final Color c) {
1157         setPixelFB(vp_ul_x + x, vp_ul_y + y, c);
1158      }
1159
1160
1161      /**
1162         Set the {@link Color} and depth of the pixel with coordinates
1163         {@code (x,y)} relative to the current viewport.
1164
1165         @param x  horizontal coordinate within the current viewport
1166         @param y  vertical coordinate within the current viewport
1167         @param c  {@link Color} for the pixel at the given viewport coordinates
1168         @param z  depth for the pixel at the given viewport coordinates
1169      */
1170      public void setPixelVP(final int x, final int y, final Color c, final double z)
1171      {
1172         setPixelVP(x, y, c);
1173         setDepthVP(x, y, z);
1174      }
1175
1176
1177      /**
1178         Set the combined RGB value of the pixel with coordinates
1179         {@code (x,y)} relative to this {@code Viewport}.
1180
1181         @param x  horizontal coordinate within this {@code Viewport}
1182         @param y  vertical coordinate within this {@code Viewport}
1183         @param c  combined RGB value for the pixel at the given {@code Viewport} coordinates
1184      */
1185      public void setPixelVP(final int x, final int y, final int c) {
1186         setPixelFB(vp_ul_x + x, vp_ul_y + y, c);
1187      }
1188
1189
1190      /**
1191         Set the combined RGB value and depth of the pixel with coordinates
1192         {@code (x,y)} relative to this {@code Viewport}.
1193
1194         @param x  horizontal coordinate within this {@code Viewport}
1195         @param y  vertical coordinate within this {@code Viewport}
1196         @param c  combined RGB value for the pixel at the given {@code Viewport} coordinates
1197      */
1198      public void setPixelVP(final int x, final int y, final int c, final double z) {
1199         setPixelVP(x, y, c);
1200         setDepthVP(x, y, z);
1201      }
1202
1203
1204      /**
1205         Set the depth of the pixel with coordinates
1206         {@code (x,y)} relative to the current viewport.
1207
1208         @param x  horizontal coordinate within the current viewport
1209         @param y  vertical coordinate within the current viewport
1210         @param z  depth for the pixel at the given viewport coordinates
1211      */
1212      public void setDepthVP(final int x, final int y, final double z) {
1213         setDepthFB(vp_ul_x + x, vp_ul_y + y, z);
1214      }
1215
1216
1217      /**
1218         Create a new {@link FrameBuffer} containing the pixel data
1219         from this {@code Viewport} rectangle.
1220
1221         @return {@code FrameBuffer} object holding pixel data from this {@code Viewport}
1222      */
1223      public FrameBuffer convertVP2FB() {
1224         final int wVP = this.getWidthVP();
1225         final int hVP = this.getHeightVP();
1226
1227         final FrameBuffer vp_fb = new FrameBuffer( wVP, hVP );
1228         vp_fb.bgColorFB = this.bgColorVP;
1229
1230         // Copy the current viewport into the new framebuffer's pixel buffer.
1231         for (int y = 0; y < hVP; ++y) {
1232            for (int x = 0; x < wVP; ++x) {
1233               vp_fb.setPixelFB( x, y, this.getPixelVP(x, y) );
1234               vp_fb.setDepthFB( x, y, this.getDepthVP(x, y) );
1235            }
1236         }
1237
1238         return vp_fb;
1239      }
1240
1241
1242      /**
1243         Write this {@code Viewport} to the specified PPM file.
1244      <p>
1245         <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Netpbm_format" target="_top">
1246                  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Netpbm_format</a>
1247
1248         @param filename  name of PPM image file to hold {@code Viewport} data
1249      */
1250      public void dumpVP2File(final String filename) {
1251         dumpPixels2File(vp_ul_x, vp_ul_y, vp_lr_x, vp_lr_y, filename);
1252      }
1253
1254
1255      /**
1256         Write this {@code Viewport} to the specified image file
1257         using the specified file format.
1258
1259         @param filename    name of the image file to hold {@code Viewport} data
1260         @param formatName  informal name of the image format
1261      */
1262      public void dumpVP2File(final String filename,
1263                              final String formatName) {
1264         dumpPixels2File(vp_ul_x, vp_ul_y, vp_lr_x, vp_lr_y,
1265                         filename, formatName);
1266      }
1267
1268
1269      /**
1270         A simple test of the {@code Viewport}.
1271      <p>
1272         It fills the viewport with a test pattern.
1273      */
1274      public void vpTestPattern() {
1275         for (int y = 0; y < this.getHeightVP(); ++y) {
1276            for (int x = 0; x < this.getWidthVP(); ++x) {
1277               final int gray = (x|y)%255;
1278               setPixelVP(x, y, new Color(gray, gray, gray));
1279            }
1280         }
1281      }
1282   }// Viewport
1283
1284
1285/*******************************************************************
1286   The following is a main() method for testing, demonstration,
1287   and documentation purposes.
1288********************************************************************/
1289
1290   /**
1291      A {@code main()} method for testing the {@code FrameBuffer} class.
1292
1293      @param args  array of command-line arguments
1294   */
1295   public static void main(String[] args) {
1296      final int w = 512;
1297      final int h = 512;
1298      final FrameBuffer fb = new FrameBuffer(w, h);
1299      fb.fbTestPattern();  // fill the framebuffer with a test pattern
1300      fb.dumpFB2File("test01.ppm");
1301
1302      // Notice the unusual notation for instantiating a new Viewport.
1303      final Viewport vp = fb.new Viewport(64, 64, 192, 320);  // 192 by 320
1304      vp.clearVP( Color.red );
1305      for (int i = 0; i < 512; ++i)
1306         fb.setPixelFB(128, i, Color.blue); // a blue vertical line
1307      for (int i = 0; i < 192; ++i)
1308         vp.setPixelVP(i, i, Color.green);  // a green diagonal line
1309
1310      fb.dumpFB2File("test02.ppm");
1311      vp.dumpVP2File("test03.ppm");
1312      fb.dumpPixels2File(32, 256-64, 511-64, 255+64, "test04.ppm"); // 416 by 128
1313
1314      final Viewport vp2 = fb.new Viewport(80, 80, 160, 160); // 160 by 160
1315      vp2.vpTestPattern();  // fill the viewport with a test pattern
1316      fb.dumpFB2File("test05.ppm");
1317
1318      final FrameBuffer fb2 = new FrameBuffer("test05.ppm");
1319      fb2.dumpFB2File("test06.ppm");
1320
1321      fb.convertRed2FB().dumpFB2File("test07.ppm");
1322      fb.convertGreen2FB().dumpFB2File("test08.ppm");
1323      fb.convertBlue2FB().dumpFB2File("test09.ppm");
1324
1325      final FrameBuffer fb3 = new FrameBuffer(600, 600);
1326      fb3.clearFB(Color.orange);
1327      final Viewport vp3 = fb3.new Viewport(44, 44, "test05.ppm");
1328      fb3.dumpFB2File("test10.ppm");
1329      fb3.new Viewport(86, 86, vp.convertVP2FB());
1330      fb3.dumpFB2File("test11.ppm");
1331      fb3.dumpFB2File("test11.png", "png");
1332      fb3.dumpFB2File("test11.gif", "gif");
1333      fb3.dumpFB2File("test11.jpg", "jpg");
1334      fb3.dumpFB2File("test11.bmp", "bmp");
1335
1336      final FrameBuffer fb4 = new FrameBuffer(1200, 600);
1337      // Create two viewports in one frameBuffer.
1338      final Viewport vp4 = fb4.new Viewport(  0, 0, "test10.ppm");
1339      final Viewport vp5 = fb4.new Viewport(600, 0, fb3);
1340      // Copy a viewport into a viewport.
1341      final Viewport vp6 = fb4.new Viewport(0, 0, 200, 200); // source
1342      final Viewport vp7 = fb4.new Viewport(1000, 400, vp6);
1343      fb4.dumpFB2File("test12.ppm");
1344
1345      // list the image file formats supported by the runtime
1346      for (final String s : ImageIO.getWriterFormatNames()) System.out.println(s);
1347   }//main()
1348}//FrameBuffer
